courses.name: Topics in Nutritional Sciences
courses.description: Supervised study in specialized topic of nutritional sciences.

courses.name: Introduction to Human Nutrition
courses.description: Basic nutrition principles, including: nutrient functions, food sources, and needs; healthy eating tools; energy balance and weight management; nutrition and fitness; nutrition through the life cycle; food safety; and consumer topics. No credit if taken after NEP 2340.

courses.name: Introduction to Human Nutrition - Honors
courses.description: Basic nutrition principles, including: nutrient functions, food sources, and needs; healthy eating tools; energy balance and weight management; nutrition and fitness; nutrition through the life cycle; food safety; and consumer topics. No credit if taken after NEP 2340.

courses.name: Food and Cultures of the World
courses.description: Trans-disciplinary approach to nutrition, considering anthropological, physiological, geographical, socioeconomic and psychological elements in world nutrition.  These ideas will be explored in the context of cuisines and cultures that are found in the US, but originate elsewhere.

courses.name: Food and Cultures of the World - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Trans-disciplinary approach to nutrition, considering anthropological, physiological, geographical, socioeconomic and psychological elements in world nutrition.  These ideas will be explored in the context of cuisines and cultures that are found in the US, but originate elsewhere.

courses.name: Introduction to Exercise and Fitness
courses.description: Provides students with practical information about exercise and physical fitness.  After taking this class, students will be prepared to be physically active, understand the "Do's and Don'ts" of exercise, and know how to live a healthy way of life.  As part of the course, students will assess their current level of activity/fitness, develop a plan for improvement, and put that plan into action.

courses.name: Career Exploration in Exercise Science
courses.description: Undergraduate course designed to provide an overview of the components important to developing an understanding and appreciation of all aspects of Exercise Science. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nutritional Food Science
courses.description: The study of components of food systems and how they are affected by processing, preservation, preparation and by techniques that improve taste, texture, flavor, appearance and nutrient retention. This course is 100% online and includes a virtual lab. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Nutritional Sciences
courses.description: Supervised study in a specialized topic of Nutritional Sciences.

courses.name: Problems in Nutritional Sciences
courses.description: Supervised study in a specialized phase of nutritional sciences.

courses.name: Landscape of Obesity
courses.description: The societal, economic, medical, behavioral, and psychological causes and results of the obesity epidemic and potential modes of treatment and prevention.  Lecture course. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Human Nutrition I
courses.description: Basic concepts of normal nutrition related to physiological/ chemical processes; changing nutrient needs during human life cycle, emphasis on adult; some social/psychological influences on dietary habits.

courses.name: Human Nutrition I - Honors
courses.description: Basic concepts of normal nutrition related to physiological/chemical processes; changing nutrient needs during human life cycle, emphasis on adult; some social/psychological influences on dietary habits.  Includes weekly discussion on controversial issues. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Organic Chemistry, Physiology, or instructor's consent.  Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Diet Therapy for Health Professionals
courses.description: Principles underlying normal nutrition and diet for health and disease. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Biology of Healthy Living
courses.description: (same as PH_THR 2420 and BIOMED 2420). Biology of inactivity as a causal factor in chronic disease.

courses.name: Nutrition Throughout the Life Span
courses.description: Nutritional requirements, challenges, community nutrition programs, and eating patterns throughout the life span with emphasis on health promotion and disease prevention; Role of beliefs, culture, socio-psychological influences, and economic resources in food selection and nutrition/health status. Lecture/discussion course.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 1034 or NEP 2340 or NEP 2380 or equivalent

courses.name: Eating Disorders
courses.description: Definition, etiology, treatment, and research related to eating disorders: anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa and binge eating disorder/obesity. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: NEP 1034 or NEP 2340 or NEP 2380 or NEP 4360

courses.name: Topics in Nutritional Science
courses.description: Instruction in specific subject matter areas in the field of food science and nutrition.

courses.name: Problems in Nutritional Sciences
courses.description: Advanced problems in a selected field of food science and nutrition.

courses.name: Problems in Nutritional Sciences - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Advanced problems in a selected field of food science and nutrition.

courses.name: International Nutrition and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Immersion into and examination of selected cultures - beliefs, practices, policies and social structures around food, physical activity and health. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Food Service I: Supervised Practice Experience
courses.description: A practicum designed to expose the student to concepts of quantity food production, evaluation of products and resources, personnel administration and application of food microbiological principles. 4 hours of supervised practice per week.
courses.prerequisites: concurrent enrollment in NEP 3280; open to students enrolled in the Coordinated Program in Dietetics only

courses.name: Nutritional Assessment Supervised Practice Experience
courses.description: Supervised practice to develop skills in screening individuals for nutrition risk; use of dietary, anthropometric, laboratory, clinical and sociocultural criteria to assess nutritional status of individuals, 8 hours of supervised practice per week. Enrollment limited to students who have taken or are concurrently enrolled in NEP 4360; Open to Nutrition and Food majors in the Coordinated Program in Dietetics only.

courses.name: Nutrition Therapy I: Supervised Practice Experience
courses.description: Practice and application of principles of nutrition care for selected disease states. 12 hours of supervised practice per week.
courses.prerequisites: Concurrently enrolled in NEP 4370; Open to students enrolled in the Coordinated Program in Dietetics only

courses.name: Teaching and Counseling Techniques in Nutrition
courses.description: Principles and theories of learning; Resources, methods and techniques for teaching food/nutrition principles and dietary guidelines; Group dynamics and facilitation; Introduction to counseling theories and methods used in nutrition care of individuals. Lecture course.

courses.name: Teaching & Counseling Techniques in Nutr. Supervised Practice Exp
courses.description: Skill development and practice in counseling individuals for health promotion and disease prevention and the teaching of food and nutrition topics to groups. 4 hours of supervised practice per week.
courses.prerequisites: concurrent enrollment in NEP 3390; Open to students enrolled in the Coordinated program in Dietetics only

courses.name: Activity Throughout the Lifespan
courses.description: Course is designed to develop knowledge and understanding of the value of physical activity across the lifespan. The physiology, psychology, and guidelines of exercise, along with the integration of nutrition with physical activity, will be explored from pregnancy through early development and into old age. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 1340; May be restricted to Nutrition and Fitness majors only during early registration

courses.name: Corporate, Community, and Personal Fitness
courses.description: Course is designed to develop the knowledge and understanding of exercise application for corporate wellness, community programs, and personal fitness. Topics covered will include exercise prescription, behavioral and motivational theories, legality, ethics and professionalism, and how these topics relate to corporate, community, and personal fitness clients. Students should be able to understand the various needs of these populations and how to apply the science of physical activity, nutrition, and human performance to each.

courses.name: Community Nutrition Supervised Practice Experience
courses.description: A practicum which explores and applies the concepts and techniques of nutrition programming in a community setting. 4 hours of supervised practice per week. Enrollment limited to students who have taken NEP 4590. Open to students enrolled in the Coordinated Program in Dietetics only.

courses.name: Prevention and Care of Athletic Injury
courses.description: Theory, practice in prevention, emergency care, rehabilitation of injuries encountered in vigorous games.
courses.prerequisites: PTH_AS 2201.  Restricted from Pre-Nutrition and Fitness majors

courses.name: Advanced Athletic Training
courses.description: Advanced study in areas of prevention, evaluation, care, and treatment and rehabilitation of athletic injuries at high school and college level. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Physiology of Exercise
courses.description: This is the basic course in exercise physiology, which applies specific principles and concepts of human physiology to the physical work situation. This course will look at ventilation, oxygen transport, cardiovascular physiology, muscle physiology and the metabolic systems; and emphasis will be given to the adaptations to exercise and training. This course will first explore basic exercise physiology and then will explore many of the applied issues pertaining to performance and health. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PTH_AS 2201; MPP 3202 or BIO_SC 3700. Restricted from Pre-Nutritional and Fitness students

courses.name: Field Training in Nutritional Sciences
courses.prerequisites: junior or senior standing and instructor's consent

courses.name: Topics in Nutrition and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Instruction in specific subject matter areas in the field of nutrition science and exercise physiology.

courses.name: Monogastric Nutrition
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 4312; cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7312, NEP 7020 and NUTRIT 7020). Principles of nutrition, feed formulation and recent research in poultry feeding. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Sports Performance and Conditioning
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 7200). Course utilizes scientific theory and applied instruction to teach procedures, techniques, and modalities used to improve physical sports performance.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Physiology and Anatomy, Kinesiology; junior or senior standing required

courses.name: Food Service Management
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 7280). Issues related to marketing and financial control in the foodservice sector. Lecture course. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Food Serv. II: Adv. Food Service Manage. Supervised Practice Exp
courses.description: A practicum tailored to apply marketing and budgetary principles in the foodservice industry. 8 hours of supervised practice per week. Enrollment limited to students with concurrent enrollment in NEP 4280. Open to students admitted to the Dietetics program.

courses.name: Human Nutrition II Laboratory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 7330). A techniques course in nutrition, usually taken concurrently with NEP 4340.

courses.name: Human Nutrition II Lecture
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 7340). Physiological and biochemical aspects of nutrition; functions of methods of measuring nutritional status; various aspects of applied nutrition. Continuation of NEP 2340.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 2340 and either BIOCHM 3630, BIOCHM 4270 or BIOCHM 4272.  Restricted from pre-Nutrition and Fitness majors

courses.name: Nutritional Assessment
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 7360). Introduction to the nutrition assessment process. The identification of dietary, anthropometric, laboratory, clinical and sociocultural parameters used to assess nutritional status of individuals. Lecture course.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000, NEP 2340.  Restricted from Pre-Nutrition and Fitness Majors

courses.name: Nutrition Therapy I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 7370). In-depth study of physiological/biochemical changes in selected disease states (cardiovascular disease, rehabilitation, diabetes and cancer); development of principles underlying nutrition therapy. Lecture course.

courses.name: Nutrition Therapy II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 7380). Evaluation, design and monitoring of the nutrition care of complex health disorders such as renal disease, trauma, and multi-system organ failure; emphasis on nutrition support (enteral and parenteral nutrition). Lecture course.

courses.name: Nutrition Therapy II: Supervised Practice Experience
courses.description: Practice in the nutrition care of complex health disorders with emphasis on nutrition support. 16 hours of supervised practice per week. Enrollment limited to students with concurrent enrollment in NEP 4380. Open to students admitted to Dietetics program only.

courses.name: Professional Development I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 7385). Course designed to provide career exploration and assessment and prepare students for the final rotations in the coordinated program in dietetics. Graded on A-F basis only.  Enrollment limited to students enrolled in the coordinated program in Dietetics.

courses.name: Issues in Dietetic Practice
courses.description: Lectures and discussions focus on issues and trends in dietetics. Discussions are used to encourage the development of skills and attitudes which foster life-long professional learning. Lecture/discussion course.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 4950 and NEP 4380; or instructor's consent

courses.name: Pediatric Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Course is designed to develop knowledge and understanding of the value of physical activity in the pediatric population. The physiology, psychology, and guidelines of exercise will be explored in the developmental process of youth. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 1340, NEP 3450 and NEP 3850 or NEP 4850

courses.name: Community Nutrition
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 7590). Public health nutrition and chronic disease prevention, food security, nutrition programs and food access, public policy, sustainable agriculture and food production systems, cultural food practices, needs assessment.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 2340 or NEP 2380.  Restricted from Pre-Nutrition and Fitness majors

courses.name: Cardiopulmonary Rehabilitation - A Multifactorial Process
courses.description: A guide to the practice of Cardiopulmonary Rehab in the 21st Century. We will explore the interdisciplinary aspects of a successful approach to the delivery of cardiac and pulmonary rehabilitation throughout a broad spectrum of patients. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 1340, NEP 3450 and NEP 3850 or NEP 4850

courses.name: Exercise Prescription
courses.description: Course investigates theory and methods of testing and prescribing exercise for circulatory fitness, body composition, muscle strength, joint and muscle ranges in motion, and posture. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: MPP 3202 or MPP 3333 and MPP 3337, PTH_AS 2201 and NEP 4850 or concurrent.  Restricted from Pre-Nutrition and Fitness majors

courses.name: Cardiovascular Exercise Physiology
courses.description: A comprehensive study through reading, lectures, discussion and laboratory experiences of the heart and circulatory systems with particular emphasis placed on acute and chronic cardiovascular adaptations to exercise in health and disease. This course will provide advanced knowledge, skills, and applications in exercise physiology necessary for students who desire to pursue careers and further study in the discipline of exercise science. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Internship in Nutritional Science and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Combines study, observation and employment in an area of exercise physiology and/or nutrition. Written reports, faculty evaluation .

courses.name: Capstone: Research in Nutritional Sciences
courses.description: Introduction to research, including the types of basic, clinical, and outcomes-based research. Defining research problems related to nutrition and exercise sciences, developing hypotheses, reviewing scientific literature, writing research protocols, analyzing data. Lecture course.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 2340 and either STAT 2500 or ESC_PS 4170 and senior standing.  Restricted from Pre-Nutrition and Fitness majors

courses.name: Nutrition Research Communication
courses.description: Analyze and interpret data; present results of a research study in manuscript and seminar presentation formats.  Emphasis on effective communication of nutrition research to scientific and lay audiences.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nutrition Research Communication - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Analyze and interpret data; present results of a research study in manuscript and seminar presentation formats.  Emphasis on effective communication of nutrition research to scientific and lay audiences.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Readings in Nutritional Sciences
courses.prerequisites: 8 hours of course work in field of subject and instructor's consent

courses.name: Nutrition Capstone
courses.description: Integration of research literature with knowledge from previous coursework, emphasis on sports nutrition research, nutrient requirements of athletes, critical evaluation of ergogenic aids. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 2340, and either MPP 3202 or BIO_SC 3700, and either STAT 1200, STAT 1300, STAT 1400 or ESC_PS 4170; Senior Standing, open to Nutrition and Fitness majors only

courses.name: Practice of Dietetics Supervised Practice Experience
courses.description: Supervised practice in providing quality nutrition services in clinical, community, management and specialty settings. 40 hours of supervised practice per week.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 3590, NEP 4280, NEP 4290, NEP 4380,NEP 4381, and NEP 4590; Open to students admitted to the Dietetics Program only

courses.name: Topics in Nutritional Science and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Instruction in specific subject matter areas in the field of food science and nutrition.

courses.name: Monogastric Nutrition
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 7312 and NUTRIT 7020; cross-leveled with NEP 4020 and AN_SCI 4312). Principles of nutrition, feed formulation and recent research in poultry feeding. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Nutritional Sciences and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Advanced problems in a selected field of food science and nutrition.

courses.name: Readings in Nutritional Sciences and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: In this course students will have the opportunity to read the literature in the area of nutrition and exercise physiology, allowing them to get more indepth knowledge in a specific area or areas.
courses.prerequisites: 15 hours course work in field of subject and instructor's consent

courses.name: Sports Performance and Conditioning
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 4200). Course utilizes scientific theory and applied instruction to teach procedures, techniques, and modalities used to improve physical sports performance.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Physiology and Anatomy, Kinesiology; junior/senior standing

courses.name: Human Nutrition II Laboratory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 4330). A techniques course in nutrition, usually taken concurrently with NEP 4340.

courses.name: Human Nutrition II Lecture
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 4340). Physiological and biochemical aspects of nutrition; functions of methods of measuring nutritional status; various aspects of applied nutrition. Continuation of NEP 2340.

courses.name: Nutritional Assessment
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 4360). Introduction to the nutrition assessment process. The identification of dietary, anthropometric, laboratory, clinical and sociocultural parameters used to assess nutritional status of individuals. Lecture course.

courses.name: Nutritional Therapy I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 4370). In-depth study of physiological/biochemical changes in selected disease states (cardiovascular disease, rehabilitation, diabetes and cancer); development of principles underlying nutrition therapy. Lecture course.

courses.name: Nutrition Therapy II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 4380). Evaluation, design and monitoring of the nutrition care of complex health disorders such as renal disease, trauma, and multi-system organ failure; emphasis on nutrition support (enteral and parenteral nutrition). Lecture course.

courses.name: Professional Development I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 4385). Course designed to provide career exploration and assessment and prepare students for the final rotations in the coordinated program in dietetics.

courses.name: The Science and Art of Nutrition
courses.description: The science of nutrition including nutrients and other active food compounds; their action, interaction, and balance in relation to human health and disease; and the processes by which they are digested, absorbed, and utilized. Emphasis on nutrient/dietary recommendations, including changing nutrient needs throughout human life span. Covers food/nutrition-related regulations and policies. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Evaluation of Food and Nutrition Research Evidence for the Consumer
courses.description: Scientific evidence interpretation/critique techniques and approaches, including research literature searches, research deigns and methodology, assessment of statistical validity. Evaluation of food/nutrition and health information sources and publication hierarchy. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Research in Nutritional Sciences and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Original investigations, usually in connection with one of the research projects of Agricultural Experiment Station. Written report required.

courses.name: Community Nutrition
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 4590). Public health nutrition and chronic disease prevention, food security, nutrition programs and food access, public policy, sustainable agriculture and food production systems, cultural food practices, needs assessment.   Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Cardiovascular Health and Fitness
courses.description: Physiology underlying best methods for obtaining and maintaining cardiovascular health and fitness. Includes exercise and weight control, plasma lipids, energy metabolism, cardiovascular dynamics, and recent research findings.

courses.name: Research in Dietetics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 4950). Introduction to research, including the relationship of basic, clinical, and outcomes-based research to dietetics practice. Defining research problems in a dietetics practice setting, developing hypotheses, reviewing scientific literature, writing research protocols, analyzing data. Lecture course.

courses.name: Sports Nutrition
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NEP 4970). Integration of research literature with knowledge from previous coursework, emphasis on sports nutrition research, nutrient requirements of athletes, critical evaluation of ergogenic aids. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Statistics, NEP 2340, Physiology; instructor's consent.  Not open to Pre-Nutrition and Fitness students

courses.name: Topics in Nutritional Sciences and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Instruction in specific subject matter areas in the field of nutrition science and exercise physiology.  May be repeated for credit. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Etiology of Obesity
courses.description: This course is designed to provide an understanding of the cause and implications of human obesity.  General topic areas covered will include: methodologies of obesity research, physiology of obesity, behavioral and environmental factors influencing obesity, obesity and disease, therapeutic approaches to obesity, and emerging topics in obesity. The structure of this course will be mixture of lectures and interactive discussions/reviews of primary research articles in these areas.  Students will be expected to present and critically evaluate research papers relevant to the field of obesity.

courses.name: Problems in Nutritional Sciences and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Individual studies include a minor research problems.

courses.name: Masters Seminar in Nutritional Sciences and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Seminar features expert presentations of current research and issue-based applications that represent the breadth of nutritional sciences and/or exercise physiology. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Masters Research in Nutritional Sciences and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Original investigation of advanced nature, leading to thesis. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Internship in Exercise Physiology
courses.description: The internship experience will take place in professionally supervised settings, and allow students to complement their academic work with employment-related experiences.  Organizations, companies and business that offer internships can be selected to match with student interests.  This experience will offer the student meaningful learning opportunities that will complement their career goals.
courses.prerequisites: must be accepted into the Exercise Physiology graduate program, 3.0 GPA or higher, completed 50% of the coursework at the masters level

courses.name: Nutritional Biochemistry of Lipids
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 8431 and NUTRIT 8310). Current concepts in the nutritional regulation of lipid metabolism. Emphasis on integrating information and interpreting current research data.

courses.name: Nutrition in Human Health
courses.description: (same as NUTRIT 8340). Nutritional aspects of maintaining human health with emphasis on micronutrients, basis for dietary recommendations, and nutrition public health initiatives.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: BIOCHM 4270 and BIOCHM 4272; 4000-level nutrition course; graduate standing or current enrollment in the Masters in Dietetics Program

courses.name: Nutritional Biochemistry I
courses.description: (same as NUTRIT 8360 and BIOCHM 8360). Provides a critical understanding of current developments in lipid metabolism in animals and humans, particularly as it relates to nutrition and health.
courses.prerequisites: BIOCHM 4270 and BIOCHM 4272; at least one 4000 level nutrition course

courses.name: Molecular Biology of Mineral Nutrition
courses.description: (same as NUTRIT 8390 and BIOCHM 8390). Current concepts of metal ion transport, intracellular metal trafficking and metal-dependent regulation of gene expression. Based entirely on research literature and taught in a tutorial format.

courses.name: Nutrient Regulation of Gene Expression
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 8438, BIOCHM 8438 and NUTRIT 8438). Current concepts with in-depth coverage of several minerals that illustrate themes in molecular mineral nutrition. Based entirely on research literature and taught in a tutorial format.

courses.name: Advanced Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Lectures, laboratory experiences, and readings in current literature to provide reasonable depth in selected areas of physiology as applied to activity and health.

courses.name: Exercise Endocrinology
courses.description: The nervous system and the endocrine system integrate to regulate the functions of the body. These systems are tightly linked and frequently one system cannot be considered without consideration of the other system. This course integrates endocrine physiology and the impact that exercise has on the endocrine response. This class will focus on the glands producing hormones, the target organs, mechanisms and how both acute and chronic exercise impacts hormone action. This is an advanced exercise physiology course designed for graduate students in Exercise Physiology or the life sciences and will consist of lectures, readings and discussion. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NEP 8850, V_BSCI 8420 or graduate standing in the Life Sciences

courses.name: Exercise Metabolism
courses.description: Review of major metabolic pathways and the effect of exercise upon them. Special topics include indirect calorimetry, EPOC, anaerobic threshold; weight control, ergogenic aids, and exercise nutrition.

courses.name: Doctorate Seminar in Nutritional Sciences and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Seminar features expert presentations of current research and issue-based topics that represent the breadth of nutritional sciences and exercise physiology. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Doctorate Research in Nutritional Sciences and Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Original investigation of advanced nature, leading to a dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.
